Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The functional consequences of antagonism in fungal communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how the Earth's climate will change over the next century is of enormous scientific, social, and economic importance. In order to make these projections of future climate, scientists will need to understand how the world's smallest organisms, fungi and bacteria, respond to changing environmental conditions. These microbes play a critical role in the Earth's carbon cycle. They decompose dead plant material, releasing carbon dioxide back into the atmosphere. Current climate models assume that the rate of this release is determined by environmental conditions, such as temperature, moisture, or soil pH. Changes in these conditions are expected to "turn the dial" on microbial activity. If it gets warmer, microbes will release more carbon dioxide; if it gets colder, microbes will release less carbon dioxide. Yet this assumption ignores a key aspect of most microbes: they are highly skilled warriors. Fungi and bacteria release an astonishing number of chemicals and compounds intended to kill their fellow microbes and colonize their territory. This warfare, however, comes at a considerable cost. A microbe must choose between using its energy for combat or using its energy for growth. In the proposed work, the researchers will quantify how microbial combat affects decomposition rates across environmental conditions, helping to understand where and when microbially-driven carbon dioxide releases will respond unpredictably to changing environmental conditions. The investigators will also train a high school student and develop outreach activities with a natural history museum.

Building on previous diversity-function studies, the researchers will develop a generalizable model to disentangle the relative importance of antagonistic competition versus environmental conditions as drivers of microbial-mediated decomposition rates. Using baseline trait data collected on 44 wood-decay fungi, 100 unique communities will be selected with varying levels of combative ability, average stress-tolerance ability, and species richness (from 3 to 12 unique species). The communities will be assembled in realistic microcosms and incubated under both optimal conditions (warm and wet) and stressful conditions (cold and dry). Total wood decomposition will be measured after 12 weeks. This study will allow the researchers to address three main questions: (1) Does community-level decomposition differ from what is predicted using the microbes' individual decomposition rates? (2) Do these differences depend on whether the individuals are combative fungi or stress-tolerant fungi? and (3) Does the relative importance of antagonistic interactions differ between stressful and optimal environmental conditions? The answers to these questions will ultimately help restructure existing climate models and better project how global carbon dioxide fluxes will change over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wood decay fungi play an important role in the terrestrial carbon cycle, governing the rate at which recalcitrant plant-bound carbon gets released into the air via respiration versus trapped in fungal biomass and returned to soil. As opposed to many other organisms (e.g., most plants), fungi are unique in that they compete through direct antagonistic interactions, in what is termed "interference competition". These combative interactions are primarily chemical, with each individual producing a suite of enzymes, organic compounds, and airborne volatiles intended to kill and inhibit growth of their neighbors. Although these activities are necessary to survive and gain access to new resources, they come at a cost: individuals must divert energy away from decomposition and towards investment in combative activities. Thus, identifying the dominant factors that dictate the combative activities of wood-decay fungi may help explain why wood-decomposition rates vary across ecosystems. Moreover, in order to predict how fungal-mediated decomposition will respond to environmental change, we must isolate the relative importance of combative interactions vs. environmental conditions on the growth and activity of these important terrestrial organisms. 

Through a combination of laboratory and field experiments, our research addresses these questions directly, demonstrating that these combative interactions are the primary drivers of carbon (C) respiration, biomass production, and wood decomposition in wood-decay fungal communities. Our work comprises three key results. First, we found that combative interactions reduce the efficiency by which fungi utilize carbon, such that fungi invest less C in biomass and have higher respiration when growing in multispecies communities relative to growing in isolation. Moreover, we show that these costs of combat are greater than the combined effects of a 6 deg-Celsius increase in temperature combined with a 20-fold increase in nitrogen---values that are equal to or greater than the average expected changes over the next century---suggesting that the response of fungal communities to environmental change has the potential to both mitigate and magnify current trends. Second, we show that when fungi interact in diverse, multispecies communities, the structure of the community dictates the relative proportion of C routed toward growth vs. combat. Specifically, communities comprised of highly competitive individuals with a dominant individual exhibited the highest respiration and lowest biomass production. Conversely, communities comprised of individuals with low competitive ability and no clear hierarchy (i.e., "intransitive" or "rock-paper-scissor" competitive relationships) had negligible reductions in carbon-use efficiency, with some even exhibiting an increase in biomass production. Lastly, we explored these patterns in the field by making use of a long-term soil warming and nitrogen addition field experiment. We show that these local-scale combative interactions ultimately overwhelm the importance of temperature and nitrogen addition, with environmental variables explaining a negligible proportion of wood decomposition. In sharp contrast, species associations and community structure explained >50% of wood decomposition, fungal respiration, and diversity across the experimental system. Taken together, these results highlight the overarching important of direct fungal interactions---rather than local environmental conditions---in dictating the structure and function of these communities.


Our work demonstrates that antagonistic fungal interactions may ultimately govern how and when fungal communities respond and adapt to climate change, with these interactions having the potential to both mitigate and magnify C respiration into the atmosphere, depending on the structure of the fungal community. Although we only consider wood decay fungi as a model system, the mechanisms explored here extend broadly to most terrestrial fungal communities---as well as many bacterial communities, which likewise participate in various forms of chemical interference. By revealing the overarching importance of direct competition as a driver of fungal functioning, this work highlights that exactly how fungi respond to environmental change will likely be fundamentally different from many other organisms (e.g., most trees and plants) which, rather than compete through direct combat, instead compete by indirectly accessing nutrients more efficiently than their neighbors. Collectively, this work fundamentally challenges the paradigm that microbial communities will respond in a linear, deterministic manner to changes in climate conditions. Further research into the causes and effects of interference competition is necessary for identifying how these communities will respond to novel environmental disturbance. Through this work, the researchers had the opportunity to train several undergraduate students, graduate students, and high school students in microbial ecology and the scientific method; and the results of this research were integral to the successful completion of co-investigator's doctoral dissertation.
